utterances: (Soundbite of protestors)

Many protestors outside the summit say because these issues like climate change and HIV/AIDS are so big, it is plain wrong that a small group of powerful leaders essentially set the agenda for the rest of the world.
But there is also another line of thinking, get the G8 countries to make specific promises and stick to them.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
Over the next few minutes we're going to visit four of the states that will decide the presidential election.
Bear in mind that election is determined state by state.
And as many people remember from the year 2000, it's even possible to lose the nationwide vote and still win the election.
No matter who wins tomorrow, the number of red and blue states on that electoral map will help determine the momentum that the winner takes to the White House.
And the states we're visiting now are the states that are commonly colored yellow or grey, which means they're too close to call.
We start with NPR's David Schaper in Indiana.
Indiana traditionally is considered the reddest of the Midwest states, favoring Republicans in 24 of the last 28 presidential elections.
Since 1940, a Democrat has carried Indiana only once.
That was back in 1964.
Four years ago, President Bush won a whopping 60 percent of the Indiana vote.
I cannot recall an election cycle where this state has been up for grabs in the general election and, therefore, being paid attention to.
Marie Eisenstein is a political scientist at Indiana University Northwest in Gary.
She says the senator from neighboring Illinois has a chance to become the first Democrat in 44 years to win here.
This would be a huge coup for the Democrats to be able to turn Indiana from a red state to a blue state.

If Barack Obama wins Indiana, it will be due, at least in part, to huge turnout in the one reliably Democratic county in the state - Lake County, which borders Chicago - and where voters like Joanne Borrow of Gary have been waiting two to three hours in line to vote early and make history.
I'm ready for the Republicans to get out of the office.
I'm ready to vote.
I can't wait to vote.
And I'll stand in a line even if it's a long way on the other side of town, I'd be in line.
With the second largest population in the state, a huge turnout in Lake County for Obama could offset lopsided margins for John McCain in rural counties in central and southern Indiana.
But Republicans are far from throwing in the towel.
Mr.
ROSS FALK(ph) (Manager, Conservative Cafe, Crown Point): The election has not happened yet.
Ross Falk, manager of the aptly-named Conservative Cafe in Crown Point where coffee is served right, says the seasoned Indiana GOP is mobilizing.
I think in the rest of the state, we actually are going to make more difference this time than ever before, you know.
I think so.
You know mid-state, southern Indiana, I still think they're traditionalists.
Another factor to consider is that Hoosiers have a tradition of splitting tickets, voting for Democrats for offices like governor, Senate, and Congress while voting for Republicans for president.
That could work in the reverse this year.
As Republican Governor Mitch Daniels is expected to win re-election Tuesday, some homes with Daniels yard signs have signs supporting Obama next to them.
David Schaper, NPR News.
And I'm Ina Jaffe in Las Vegas where the 60,000 members of the Culinary Workers Union are a force to be reckoned with at election time.
74-year old Clester Nelson is one of the union's hundreds of canvassers.
As he was setting out from the union hall yesterday, he said that electing Barack Obama would be the fulfillment of a family prophecy.
My grandfather, he was a slave.
And when I was about eight years old, he said, son, maybe by the time you get to be an adult, they'll have a black president.
There are now more Democrats for Nelson to contact than there were just a year ago.
Democrats have overtaken Republicans in voter registration by a margin of more than a hundred thousand.
Meanwhile, the state's been hit hard by the economic crisis.
The unemployment rate here is above the national average, and the state has the highest foreclosure rate in the country.
Clester Nelson says that's on the mind of everyone he meets.
You bump into people that will tell you - say, I've got to move, and I really don't know where I would move because I don't have any money.
I lost my job.
Las Vegas has always provided the mother lode of Democratic votes in Nevada.
Republicans hold sway in the state's rural counties.
But John McCain has his backers in the Las Vegas area too.
Some of his evangelical supporters spent Sunday afternoon gathered in a hotel ballroom south of the strip to hear speakers including Pastor John Knapp.
Do every single thing that you can to make sure that the biblical values that this nation was founded on are pushed forwards in this next election.
What Craig and Cheryl Smith have been doing for John McCain is praying.
Lord, please have mercy on us as a nation, and please have Mr. McCain be president.
Our pastor likes to say that it's prayer is the work.
You think a lot and do all these hands-on things, but prayer is what is the real work.
But leaving nothing to chance or heaven, John McCain and Sarah Palin will each hold rallies in Nevada later today.
Ina Jaffe, NPR News, Las Vegas.
This is Adam Hochberg.
North Carolina has been a red state in each of the last seven presidential elections.
If that changes this year, newcomers like Melissa Coleman will be part of the reason.
Who's mommy going to vote for in the election?
Obama.
Yeah.
Who are we not going to vote for?
McCain.
McCain.

Coleman with her husband and kids moved from Massachusetts to North Carolina earlier this year settling in a recently built subdivision in the sprawling suburbs of Raleigh, the nation's third fastest growing metropolitan area.
She says most of her neighbors are equally new to the state, and they've brought some new political attitudes with them too.
The politics in North Carolina are changing dramatically.
I mean, people are flocking in here from New England and pretty much Pennsylvania and up, so we're actually considered a swing state.
It was a big surprise for me, for sure.
I'll stick to the bullfights, she says.
They're a lot nicer.
The county that includes Raleigh and its suburbs went for President Bush in the 2004 election, but polls suggest Barack Obama has a double-digit lead in the county now.
To overcome Obama's strength in fast-growing urban areas, John McCain has to do well in rural communities and more established parts of North Carolina.
And he has to motivate members of the Republican base such as 75-year-old Correnn Watkins who cast an early ballot for McCain last week.
I'm a Southern Baptist, so I am conservative.
In fact, we pray every night at 9 for the nation and that McCain is elected.
Statewide polls show the North Carolina race too close to call.
So the number of newcomers who vote versus the number of longtime residents may determine whether Watkins' prayers are answered.
Adam Hochberg, NPR News, Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
I'm Greg Allen in Miami.
The math here in Florida is simple.
Democrats usually carry south Florida, Republicans dominate the north.
The central part of the state, what's called the I-4 Corridor, is the battleground where elections are decided.
Democrats have registered twice as many new voters this year as Republicans and hold a 650,000 voter edge statewide.
The question is how many of these new voters will turn out tomorrow.
It's a close race in Florida, but Diane Hansborough, who supports John McCain, says she's not worried about the polls.
No.
You have to keep fighting and you have to go out.
You have to knock on doors.
You have to get people as much as you can to understand how bad it would be if we get Obama, and I firmly believe that.
In Florida, one out of every four voters is over 65.
McCain has enjoyed some of his strongest support among senior citizens.
But recent polls suggest it's eroding.
Among the factors cited: the worsening economy and his selection of Sarah Palin as his running mate.
Helen Rutledge is a retiree who lives in Boca Raton.
Sometimes, I look at McCain and I like him, but I worry because his health is not the best and his age isn't.
And I don't think an inexperienced little girl from Alaska should step into the presidency.
Since it's Florida, all eyes will be watching for voting snags tomorrow.
Expect plenty of lawyers at the polls.
Greg Allen, NPR News, Miami.
(Soundbite of music)
We're going to be asking for your help on Election Day.
When you vote, let us know if you encounter problems like broken machines or long waits.
You can contact us by text message, voicemail, via Twitter, or even by iPhone.
And you can learn more by going to npr.org/votereport.
And you can read predictions for every state's presidential, Senate, House and gubernatorial elections in the ""Political Junkie"" column from NPR's political editor Ken Rudin.
His column will be up later this morning at npr.org/politicaljunkie.
And on election night, you can quiz Ken and post your own comments at npr.org.
This is Morning Edition from NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
As NPR's David Welna reports, the closer the polarized Senate gets to November's elections, the harder it's been for Democrats to move a pile of unfinished business.
Thirty-one House Republicans joined 241 Democrats in giving final passage to the long-stalled unemployment bill.
Right before the vote, majority leader Steny Hoyer deplored how the GOP had tied up the bill so long in the Senate, where only two Republicans voted for the measure.
Millions of people had lost their unemployment insurance because we could not get 60 votes in the Senate.
Had almost every Democrat saying, we need help now.
Even after Senate Democrats mustered a 60-vote supermajority and broke the filibuster, Republicans insisted on dragging out the debate one more day before allowing a final vote.
Rhode Island Democrat Sheldon Whitehouse vented his frustration on the Senate floor.
